<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.2 is: A for loop shall be well-formed.
The three clauses of a for statement are the:
1. First clause shall be empty or an expression whose set the value of the loop counter or define and intialize the loop counter.
2. Second clause shall be an expression that has no persistent side effects, and shall use the loop counter and optionally loop control flags, and shall not use any other object that is modified in the for loop body.
3.Third clause shall be an expression whose modify only the value of the loop counter, and shall not use objects that are modified in the for loop body.
4. There shall only be one loop counter in a for loop, which shall not be modified in for loop body. A loop control flag is defined as single identifier denoting an object with Boolean type that is used in the second clause. The behaviour of a for loop body includes the behaviour of any functions called within that statement. 
</misra_rule>

<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_irq_get_controller:
```c
static struct metal_irq_controller *metal_irq_get_controller(int irq)
{
	struct metal_list *node;
	struct metal_irq_controller *cntr;

	metal_list_for_each(&irq_cntrs, node) {
		int irq_base, irq_end;

		cntr = (struct metal_irq_controller *)
		       metal_container_of(node, struct metal_irq_controller,
					  node);
		irq_base = cntr->irq_base;
		irq_end = irq_base + cntr->irq_num;
		if (irq >= irq_base && irq < irq_end) {
			return cntr;
		}
	}
	return NULL;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: Rule 14.2 concerns the structure of the for statement and the loop counter. The only code fragments that can affect compliance are the loop counter declaration and the for loop itself (here implemented via the macro metal_list_for_each). The macro expansion determines the three clauses (initialization, condition, iteration) and must be inspected for: single loop-counter usage, absence of persistent side effects in the condition, and that the increment expression modifies only the loop counter. Other lines in the function (declaration of cntr, irq_base/irq_end, the assignments, the if test and the return) are ordinary statements in the loop body and are not themselves part of the for-statement clauses; they do not alter the structure of the for statement and therefore do not need to be separately flagged for Rule 14.2. (Note: the macro expansion and any macros/functions used inside the body should be examined by investigators — the provided suspicious fragments include the macro usage so that expansion can be checked.)
